title: United Arab Emirates - Conflict Data
org: Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project (ACLED)

bites.title: Map of locations
bite: Military Forces of the United Arab Emirates (2004-)

On 17 August 2020, Emirati coastguards confronted 8 Iranian fishing boats which it claimed violated its territorial waters northwest of Sir Bu Nu'Ayr island. Iran's Foreign Ministry claimed Emirati coastguards seized a fishing ship and shot dead 2 of the fishermen.
Government of the United Arab Emirates (2004-)
Middle East Eye; Reuters; Khaleej Times

Security measures: On 4 April 2020, the government of the Emirate of Dubai imposed strict measures to prevent the spread of the coronavirus, expanding measures previously put in place by the federal government. Only one member of a household can now leave home for essential shopping, only people working in support sectors can go to work, and all people are required to wear masks and gloves in public. On 24 April, Dubai cut its 24-hour lockdown to a 10:00 pm to 6:00 am curfew. Dubai lifted some further restrictions on 24 May, allowing cinemas, indoor gyms, and child education and treatment centres to reopen.
Government of the United Arab Emirates (2004-)
Security measures: On 25 March 2020, the United Arab Emirates implemented a full closure of airspace amidst the spread of the coronavirus.
Government of the United Arab Emirates (2004-)

Security measures: On 8 March 2020, amidst the spread of the coronavirus, the UAE closed all schools and universities. On 22 March, the UAE closed all public and private beaches, parks, swimming pools (public and private), cinemas, fitness center's. On March 26, the UAE government introduced a nightly curfew from 8 pm to 6 am. On 24 April 23, the curfew time was changed to 10 pm to 6 am. On 25 June, the restrictions were loosened and the curfew lifted completely. Shopping malls and indoor spaces must adhere to a maximum number of customers.
On 20 December 2019, a group of Indians held a protest in Dubai against India's controversial citizenship law. [size=no report]

On 12/5/2019, two crude oil tankers owned by Saudi shipping firm Bahri, a UAE-flagged fuel bunker barge and a Norwegian-registered oil products tanker were subjected to alleged sabotage operations near UAE territorial waters in the Gulf of Oman, east of Fujairah. The US and some of its Gulf allies accused Iran of being behind the attacks, although Iran has vehemently rejected any involvement.
Police Forces of United Arab Emirates (2004-)
On 11/11/2018, police dispersed hundreds of migrant workers who were protesting on Reem Island against unpaid salaries. [size=hundreds]
Military Forces of Yemen (2016-) Supreme Political Council

Al-Houthi forces claim to have targeted the Abu Dhabi airport using a remotely controlled drone loaded with explosives. The Abu Dhabi airport reported an 'incident' but stated via twitter that the incident 'has not affected operations at AUH and flights continue to arrive and depart as scheduled'.

On May 1st, around 250 workers gathered in front of a Dubai-based contracting company in Al Quoz area behind Al Khail Gate on Monday. They held a peaceful protest demanding payment of their pending salaries.
